quizzes.question: Rearrange the code to open a file, read its contents, print them, and then close the file.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Reading Files[/h1]

The contents of a file that has been opened in text mode can be read using the [b]read [/b]method. [code format="py"]file = open("filename.txt", "r")
[b]cont = file.read()[/b]
print(cont)
file.close()[/code]
[note]This will print all of the contents of the file "filename.txt".[/note]

quizzes.question:
How many characters would be in each line printed by this code, if one character is one byte?
file = open("filename.txt", "r")
for i in range(21):
  print(file.read(4))
file.close()
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Reading Files[/h1]

To read only a certain amount of a file, you can provide a number as an argument to the [b]read [/b]function. This determines the number of [b]bytes [/b]that should be read. 
You can make more calls to [b]read [/b]on the same file object to read more of the file byte by byte. With no argument, [b]read [/b]returns the rest of the file. [code format="py"]file = open("filename.txt", "r")
print(file.read(16))
print(file.read(4))
print(file.read(4))
print(file.read())
file.close()[/code]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to open a file, read its content and print its length.
[!raw!]
file = {0}("filename.txt", "r")
str = file.{1}()
print(len(str))
file.close()
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Reading Files[/h1]

After all contents in a file have been read, any attempts to read further from that file will return an empty string, because you are trying to read from the end of the file.[code format="py"]file = open("filename.txt", "r")
file.read()
print("Re-reading")
print(file.read())
print("Finished")
file.close()[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw"]>>>
Re-reading

Finished
>>>[/code]

quizzes.question:
If the file test.txt has 7 lines of content, what will the following expression return?
len(open("test.txt").readlines())
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Reading Files[/h1]

To retrieve each line in a file, you can use the [b]readlines [/b]method to return a list in which each element is a line in the file.
[b]For example:[/b][code format="py" ]file = open("filename.txt", "r")
print(file.readlines())
file.close()[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
['Line 1 text \n', 'Line 2 text \n', 'Line 3 text']
>>>[/code]
You can also use a [b]for [/b]loop to iterate through the lines in the file: [code format="py" ]file = open("filename.txt", "r")

[b]for [/b]line [b]in [/b]file:
    print(line)

file.close() [/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
Line 1 text

Line 2 text

Line 3 text
>>>[/code]
[note]In the output, the lines are separated by blank lines, as the [b]print [/b]function automatically adds a new line at the end of its output.[/note]
